entry.title: 9 circles of LaTeX hell. Rookie edition.
entry.summary:
1. Messing with labels

If I could give a younger version of myself a single advice on the LaTeX, it would be "Thou shall give good names to your labels, for you shall permanently reuse your documents". By good name I mean something like section:introduction, subsection:model_assumption, eq:drift_approximation, table:comparison_schemes, not a mess of intro, assum1, DrAppr, CompScheme. You should do it for two reasons:

  • Starting the name of the label from the type (section, subsection, equation, figure) is a good idea, because it makes so much easier to use autocompletion without scrolling through all those names...
  • Which you will forget sooner than you believe! Keep in mind that you will reuse most of your reports dozens of time, so save your time

Few packages which will make your life easier:

  • showonlyref

2. Messing with references

Reference properly

3. Messing with long formulas

Know the difference between multline, align, grouped etc.

The beautiful world of equation-like environments in LaTeX remains mostly unexplored. Negligence leads to undesirable - and unreadable! - consequences, especially if you are dealing with half-page long formulas. Here is a short guide:

  • {equation} is used for one-line equations only
  • {multline} is used for ONE equation, splitted on several lines, with cascade-style alignment
  • {gather} is used for centering a GROUP of equations (with separate label for EACH equation). Environment {gathered} is used inside an environment {equation} and does the same job as {gather}, but allocating ONE label to the group
  • {align} (and, respectively, {aligned}) allows a custom alignment for multiline equations (or group of equations).

4. Messing with bibliography

Alternative title would be a "life-changing magic of using JabRef". Let me convince you why JabRef is adorable (if you are not using it already):

  • It gives you several powerful search-engines (Springer, GoogleScholar etc.) which allow you to add a BibTex reference to your bibliography without lurking through the websites in vain to find the copy-pasteable text.
  • It keeps your bibliography organized. If you need to find a specific paper and change, for example, its status from a preprint to a journal publication - you do it simply by sorting your entries by, for example, a year, and save yourself time which you would otherwise spent on scrolling through txt file which contains few hundreds entries.
  • Since it treats your library as a true database, you have an access to all the good database features as export\import to another format, removing dublicates, autogenerate keys in a proper format.
  • JabRef is free, cross-platform and open source (consider a donation!)

5. Not tracking changes

latexdiff, vimdiff, changes

Make copies

6. Not playing well with the others

How to collaborate and track changes

7. Messing with code and algorithms

Applies mostly to working reports.

8. Not fancifying

LaTeX is powerful! Why not using it properly?

9. Loosing track of packages

It should be obvious, but still: it is not a good idea to copy-paste the same once-and-for-all adjusted header of your TeX document in all the documents, with all the packages which you are have used only once or twice in your life. Try to keep it simple, and you will avoid:

  • increased compilation time
  • compilation problems when using some custom template (for example, journal or conference template)
  • any package manag?
entry.content:
1. Messing with labels

If I could give a younger version of myself a single advice on the LaTeX, it would be "Thou shall give good names to your labels, for you shall permanently reuse your documents". By good name I mean something like section:introduction, subsection:model_assumption, eq:drift_approximation, table:comparison_schemes, not a mess of intro, assum1, DrAppr, CompScheme. You should do it for two reasons:

  • Starting the name of the label from the type (section, subsection, equation, figure) is a good idea, because it makes so much easier to use autocompletion without scrolling through all those names...
  • Which you will forget sooner than you believe! Keep in mind that you will reuse most of your reports dozens of time, so save your time

Few packages which will make your life easier:

  • showonlyref

2. Messing with references

Reference properly

3. Messing with long formulas

Know the difference between multline, align, grouped etc.

The beautiful world of equation-like environments in LaTeX remains mostly unexplored. Negligence leads to undesirable - and unreadable! - consequences, especially if you are dealing with half-page long formulas. Here is a short guide:

  • {equation} is used for one-line equations only
  • {multline} is used for ONE equation, splitted on several lines, with cascade-style alignment
  • {gather} is used for centering a GROUP of equations (with separate label for EACH equation). Environment {gathered} is used inside an environment {equation} and does the same job as {gather}, but allocating ONE label to the group
  • {align} (and, respectively, {aligned}) allows a custom alignment for multiline equations (or group of equations).

4. Messing with bibliography

Alternative title would be a "life-changing magic of using JabRef". Let me convince you why JabRef is adorable (if you are not using it already):

  • It gives you several powerful search-engines (Springer, GoogleScholar etc.) which allow you to add a BibTex reference to your bibliography without lurking through the websites in vain to find the copy-pasteable text.
  • It keeps your bibliography organized. If you need to find a specific paper and change, for example, its status from a preprint to a journal publication - you do it simply by sorting your entries by, for example, a year, and save yourself time which you would otherwise spent on scrolling through txt file which contains few hundreds entries.
  • Since it treats your library as a true database, you have an access to all the good database features as export\import to another format, removing dublicates, autogenerate keys in a proper format.
  • JabRef is free, cross-platform and open source (consider a donation!)

5. Not tracking changes

latexdiff, vimdiff, changes

Make copies

6. Not playing well with the others

How to collaborate and track changes

7. Messing with code and algorithms

Applies mostly to working reports.

8. Not fancifying

LaTeX is powerful! Why not using it properly?

9. Loosing track of packages

It should be obvious, but still: it is not a good idea to copy-paste the same once-and-for-all adjusted header of your TeX document in all the documents, with all the packages which you are have used only once or twice in your life. Try to keep it simple, and you will avoid:

  • increased compilation time
  • compilation problems when using some custom template (for example, journal or conference template)
  • any package manag?

entry.title: Contacts
entry.summary:
You can write me an e-mail to firstname.lastname@univ-grenoble-alpes.fr or firstname.lastname@u-cergy.fr.

My postal address is:

Off. 132
LJK, Bâtiment MAG
700 Avenue Centrale
38401 Saint-Martin-d'Hères
France

For those, who are already here and are willing to visit me in person (and, optionally, to offer me a free lunch): Office 132 is on the first floor, on the south side of building, with a cute soviet poster on the door.

entry.title: Explain me like I'm 5: Basics of probability theory
entry.summary:
Probability space

Formal definition:

Plain English explanation:

Filtration - available information about the process, can be considered as logs. Natural filtration - contains all the information about the given process, and only this information.
Process is adapted to filtration if the information about the state of the given process at time \(t\) contains at \(\sigma\)-algebra \(\mathcal{F}\).

Q: Why do we need a \(\sigma\)-algebra when talking about stochastic processes? A: Just to restrict ourselves to the case when all the events we are talking about can be assigned a probability measure

Martingales: local martingales, sub- and supermartingales, semimartingales,

Markov property

Solutions of SDEs
entry.content:
Probability space

Formal definition:

Plain English explanation:

Filtration - available information about the process, can be considered as logs. Natural filtration - contains all the information about the given process, and only this information.
Process is adapted to filtration if the information about the state of the given process at time \(t\) contains at \(\sigma\)-algebra \(\mathcal{F}\).

Q: Why do we need a \(\sigma\)-algebra when talking about stochastic processes? A: Just to restrict ourselves to the case when all the events we are talking about can be assigned a probability measure

Martingales: local martingales, sub- and supermartingales, semimartingales,

Markov property

Solutions of SDEs

entry.title: Research
entry.summary:
Latest news:

  • 29.05.2019 Very approximative summary on lecture on ergodicity for Probability Reading Group is here
  • 11.04.2019 Freshly uploaded slides for today's talk at Seminaire du departement DATA are here
  • 25.03.2019 Congrès Math.en.Jeans 2019 will take place on campus Saint-Martin-d'Hères on 29-31 of March. Everyone (within the age limits from 4 to \(\infty\)) is invited!
  • 20.03.2019 PDF-version of the last lecture "Construction of the Lebesgue Integral" on the Probability Reading Group is here. Next meeting will take place on 3d April in room 106 (Bâtiment IMAG). Don't miss!
  • 07.03.2019 thrilled to be invited to CSA 2019 in Norway! See you there on August 25-30.
  • 11.01.2019 Version 2 of "Parametric inference for multidimensional hypoelliptic ergodic diffusion with full observations" is online on HAL
  • 12.11.2018 Slides of my talk for a working group MathBio Grenoble are available here.
  • 04.08.2018 Working process on CEMRACS project "Horizontal Gene Transfer and Evolutionary rescue" can be now tracked with the help of our GitHub repository. It includes codes for the simulation of individual-based model of bacteria population, deterministic model of a population density for large population size, and a corresponding Hamilton-Jacobi equation for small mutation probability. My collaborators are Susely Figueroa Iglesias and Samuel Nordmann.
  • 09.06.2018 Slides for my presentation at Journées de Statistique in Paris-Saclay are here and for DynStoch 2018 in Porto are here. Both of them sum up the preprint which you may find on ArXiv.
  • 20.03.2018 Updated codes on GitHub: now much more faster with the help of Rcpp!
  • 14.02.2018 Added a repository on GitHub with codes of experiments (contrast estimator + dimensionality of noise tests)
  • 10.02.2018 This page is cold and empty. In the meanwhile, you can check my Master Thesis and corresponding slides.
entry.content:
Latest news:

  • 29.05.2019 Very approximative summary on lecture on ergodicity for Probability Reading Group is here
  • 11.04.2019 Freshly uploaded slides for today's talk at Seminaire du departement DATA are here
  • 25.03.2019 Congrès Math.en.Jeans 2019 will take place on campus Saint-Martin-d'Hères on 29-31 of March. Everyone (within the age limits from 4 to \(\infty\)) is invited!
  • 20.03.2019 PDF-version of the last lecture "Construction of the Lebesgue Integral" on the Probability Reading Group is here. Next meeting will take place on 3d April in room 106 (Bâtiment IMAG). Don't miss!
  • 07.03.2019 thrilled to be invited to CSA 2019 in Norway! See you there on August 25-30.
  • 11.01.2019 Version 2 of "Parametric inference for multidimensional hypoelliptic ergodic diffusion with full observations" is online on HAL
  • 12.11.2018 Slides of my talk for a working group MathBio Grenoble are available here.
  • 04.08.2018 Working process on CEMRACS project "Horizontal Gene Transfer and Evolutionary rescue" can be now tracked with the help of our GitHub repository. It includes codes for the simulation of individual-based model of bacteria population, deterministic model of a population density for large population size, and a corresponding Hamilton-Jacobi equation for small mutation probability. My collaborators are Susely Figueroa Iglesias and Samuel Nordmann.
  • 09.06.2018 Slides for my presentation at Journées de Statistique in Paris-Saclay are here and for DynStoch 2018 in Porto are here. Both of them sum up the preprint which you may find on ArXiv.
  • 20.03.2018 Updated codes on GitHub: now much more faster with the help of Rcpp!
  • 14.02.2018 Added a repository on GitHub with codes of experiments (contrast estimator + dimensionality of noise tests)
  • 10.02.2018 This page is cold and empty. In the meanwhile, you can check my Master Thesis and corresponding slides.
